title: How to Make Crafts Using Catalogs

steps.headline: Gather up any catalogs that you like.
steps.description: You never know when you might need them, so find a neat place to stack them in readiness for making crafts. Choose ones that have expired. Catalogs that haven't expired may still be useful. Check through non-expired ones before adding to the craft pile, removing coupons and taking note of specials, etc. so that you don't miss out on the bargains.

steps.headline: Clear a large space in your work area.
steps.description: You'll need a space big enough to contain multiple catalog clippings.

steps.headline: Choose the right sort of catalogs.
steps.description: Ideal catalogs for this craft include any catalog that contains pictures of plants or flowers. You will also need a sheet of blank or construction paper (preferably brown so that it looks like soil), scissors, glue or tape. You could also use white paper, and use coloring pencils or markers to draw on soil, grass, sky and trees, etc.

steps.headline: Comb through all of the selected catalogs carefully.
steps.description: Mark the pages that have pictures you want with a post-it note, or something of that sort (even strips torn from another catalog can make useful bookmarks––just recycle them when you've finished with them). As you select images, check each side of the selected pages to make sure that cutting out your picture won't involve cutting through another, more interesting one.

steps.headline: Cut all your pictures out.
steps.description: Place them somewhere that is easy to see them all, alongside the construction paper.

steps.headline: Arrange the flower pictures on the construction paper.
steps.description: Do this without gluing anything down, so that you can change things around until you're absolutely happy with the final design.

steps.headline: Affix the images permanently.
steps.description: After you've placed all your pictures, glue them down. Take care not to knock unglued ones out of the way as you work.

steps.headline: Done.
steps.description: You can now stick the image up somewhere or use it in some other craft project that you have in mind. This picture might also make good wrapping paper; be sure that the glue holds the images really well if you intend using it for this purpose.

steps.headline: Make menus that can be used in child's play or for a stage production.
Choose the catalogs.
steps.description: Catalogs useful for this craft will be any that have pictures of food in them, such as grocery or supermarket catalogs.

steps.headline: Take a sheet of paper that you can form a menu shape from.
steps.description: Fold it in half.

steps.headline: Write the name of your restaurant on top.
Go through the chosen catalogs to find food pictures.
steps.description: Mark the pictures you're going to use, checking both sides of the page for any other pictures you might be cutting through and that might be more interesting. Don't use too many pictures for your menu. You will need to also add text, so it won't be all images.

steps.headline: After you've found all your pictures, arrange them on your menu, without gluing them at this stage.
steps.description: Rearrange the images until you're happy with the layout. When it all fits and you've left plenty of space to write the price and name of the dish beside each image, it's time to glue down the images.

steps.headline: Wait for your menu to dry.
Finish the menu.
steps.description: Write the name of the dish and any explanation next to the relevant image. Also write down a price. Repeat for each image you've added. If you like, you could also add other embellishments, such as a ribbon looped around the center and tied with a dangling tassel, stickers, fake gems, or other such items.

steps.headline: Use the menu.
steps.description: Either use for playtime or for a stage prop.

steps.headline: Make fashion designer booklets that help you keep abreast of the latest fashions.
steps.description: You can use the images to mix and match ideas, to put together a book of wanted clothing or to simply inspire your own designing and sewing ideas.

steps.headline: Find the right catalogs.
steps.description: For this project, you will need pictures of clothes––lots of them. Go through catalogs and mark all of the pictures. Check each side of the page, to be sure you have the best image from the same page. Shoe and accessory catalogs should be included in the catalogs you choose.

steps.headline: Start cutting out the clothes.
steps.description: Cut out both pieces of a suit, or if you're feeling very adventurous, cut off all the sleeves and cut off the pant legs, to allow you to create entirely new clothing styles. You might want to cut out the heads of the models as well as their clothes.

steps.headline: Save all the cut out clothes.
Make a booklet.
steps.description: Find two or more pieces of paper. Fold them into a booklet shape, then staple or glue them together to create four or more pages. On the cover, put the picture of your favorite model with all their clothes on. On each page, trace the outline of a shirt-and-pants ensemble or of a person on which you can place the clothing. Or, you can add the clothing pieces in boxes, randomly or any other preferred way.

steps.headline: Arrange the clothing in your fashion booklet, make zany, interesting, fun and realistic creations using the cutout pieces of clothing.
Add any text you'd like to accompany the images.
steps.description: For example, you might wish to be reminded as to why you've paired some items together, perhaps for a sewing project or items you'd like to find when out shopping.

steps.headline: Keep in a place where it's easy to find.
steps.description: If you've made the booklet purse size, you can pop it in your bag when you head out shopping for new clothes.
